title: North (Hudson) River - Shore and skyline - Manhattan - 59th Street - George Washington Bridge.

text:
George Washington Bridge: Three views showing the construction period attendant to this public work that connects Manhattan to New Jersey. The first two views are of the New York approach, while the third is of the Jersey side.
Views: 1-2 February 1931
View : 3 August 1929
George L. Balgue
title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [Construction of the bridge, connecting Manhattan, New York to New Jersey.]

title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [Construction of the bridge, connecting Manhattan, New York to New Jersey.]

text:
George Washington Bridge: A northward view up the North (Hudson) River showing the cables and piers of the uncompleted structure. Manhattan is on the right and New Jersey on the left. Note the United States Navy vessels off of Riverside Drive. View No. 2 is a close up of the Manhattan base. Note here, at the left, the small lighthouse on a promontory, the historic significance of which goes back to the Revolution, as it was from here that the chains extended across the River. Apartments seen in the background form the area known as Washington Heights.

May 10, 1930

Gift of W. A. Lucas
title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [North (Hudson) River.]

text:
Four square blocks of modern apartment buildings; sacrificed to make clearance for the Manhattan approach to the George Washington Bridge, at approximately West 181st Street, in Manhattan.

Late 1930.?

Ewing Galloway.
title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge.

text:
(1)
The George Washington Bridge, as viewed southwestward across Riverside Drive and the Hudson River, from Fort Tryon Park. This structure which unites the two states, terminates on the far side at Englewood, New Jersey.

June 22, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
(Not a dry mount item).

(2)
The same.

July 30, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
An earlier view from approximately the same vantage point, showing the spun cables connecting the pier heads prior to the suspension of the cat-walk.

October 5, 1930.

text:
Riverside Drive, south from a point on a line with West 177th Street (left) showing the area to the south of the new George Washington Bridge (approaches under construction at this date). The apartment houses appearing on the bluff face on Haven Avenue.

Note the frame dwelling remaining. This is between 173rd and 175th Streets and stands in (present) J. Hood Wright Park. For individual pictures of same, see files under that classification.

To the extreme right appears the white buildings comprising the Cornell University--Presbyterian Hospital Center (Cornell Medical Center).

Sept. 29, 1931
P. L. Sperr, photographer

A general view of the midtown Manhattan Central Park zone as photographed northwestward from the Chrysler Bldg. In the lower right corner is Lexington Avenue; Park Ave. is towards the center. The tower ornamentation of the Grand Central Bldg. is in the lower left. In the background is the Hudson River, its Jersey shore, and the Geo. Washington Bridge crossing same.

About 1931

Ewing Galloway
title: General view - Midtown Manhattan - Centarl Park.

text:
(1)
Riverside Drive, from a point on a line with West 178th Street (right, George Washington Bridge) to West 181st Street (left, also known as the Plaza Lafayette) showing a general view northeastward of that area, popularly called the Heights. Towards the left center one sees apartment houses that stand on the Revolutionary Fort Washington site.

September 29, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same. The photographer is viewing northeastward from the north side of the new George Washington Bridge which extends out from West 177th and 178th (right) Streets. The small cottage shown is the Monastery of St. Clare which occupies a strip of land between Riverside Terrace (raised portion of the Drive) and Haven Ave. and bearing No. 328 upon the latter.

September 29, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

P. L. Sperr.

George Washington Bridge, in its majestic span of the Hudson River; from West 181st Street in Manhattan, to Fort Lee in New Jersey; as seen looking west to the Palisades from Manhattan. An added feature of this Bridge, are, the two observation platforms, atop both towers.

About 1932.

Wurts Brothers.

title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [North (Hudson) River.]

text:
An aerial view of George Washington Bridge, east from New Jersey, across to the Bronx. The older Washington Bridge, which spans the Harlem River, may be seen in the background, in the upper right corner.

January 1932.

International Photos.

folder: Central Park & Aerial view from Radio City., Manhattan, NY
text:
Central Park: Aerial View from Radio City (Sixth Avenue and 51st Street), showing the Park and the Fifth Avenue side. In the center foreground may be seen the Pond, north of it the Mall, then the Lake, of which the eastern bay is at the northern end of the Mall and the main body on the west side of the Park, about 70th to 80th Streets. The bare spot further north is the site of the old reservoir; above it may be seen the north reservoir, still in use. The buildings of the Metropolitan Museum of Art may be seen on the Fifth Avenue side at 81st Street.

August 9, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

The same, another view. In the southwestern quarter of the Park may be seen a ball ground, and north of it the Meadow or Green. The 72nd Street cross drive separates the Green and the Lake.

August 9, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

The same, also showing the West Side of town and the Hudson River. The Riverside Church, at 122nd Street, and the George Washington Bridge, at 181st Street, stand out very clearly.

August 9, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Central Park - Aerial view from Radio City.

folder: Fort Washington Aven & 174th Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
J. Hood Wright Park: A set of 3 views of that playground area extending between Fort Washington and Haven Avenues, and W. 173rd to 176th Streets. The photographer is near Fort Washington Avenue and 174th Street and is viewing northward in No. 1 to show the new George Washington Bridge, northward in No. 2 to show apartment structures between Pinehurst and Fort Washington Avenues (seen on right), and southeastward in No. 3 towards the southeasterly corner.

October 12, 1934.
Views 1,2 and 3

P.L. Sperr
title: Manhattan: Fort Washington Aven - 174th Street

folder: Fort Washington Aven & Northern Avenue, Manhattan, NY
text:
Fort Washington Ave. (foreground) at the S.W. corner of Northern Ave. (right). At this point, Overlook Terrace, both of these thoroughfares lose their identity, the former continuing through Fort Tryon Park as Park Drive. The photographer is viewing southwestward towards the George Washington Bridge from this point at the Park entrance, which would be on the right if seen.

June 22, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Fort Washington Aven - Northern Avenue

text:
George Washington Bridge
179th Street and Riverside Drive, Manhattan

Federal Art Project
"Changing New York"
Berenice Abbott, photographer

[Note: negative at Museum of the City of New York]
Code II A-4b
Jan. 17, 1936

p. 176, Changing New York
title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge.

text:
The George Washington Bridge, a steel structure, connecting Manhattan at West 181st Street with Fort Lee, New Jersey. The view is westward from Manhattan, and just south of the Bridge. Control of this engineering masterpiece, is in the hands of the N.Y. Port Authority, who will charge a toll for crossing same. These 4 views are more or less similar, and are all by the same photographer.

1936.

Walter L. Bogert.
title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [Connecting Manhattan at West 181st Street with Fort Lee, New Jersey.]

folder: La Salle Place & 125th Street (West), Manhattan, NY
text:
La Salle Street (left) west from W. 125th Street (right). The 2 story structure at the convergence of these thoroughfares is the McGuire Building. Note the sign over same. View No. 2 emphasizes W. 125th Street and upon which appears the arched span carrying the subway lines at Broadway.

May 4, 1938.
Views 1 and 2

P.L. Sperr

folder: La Salle Place & 125th Street (West), Manhattan, NY
text:
La Salle Street (left) west from W. 125th Street (right). The 2 story structure at the convergence of these thoroughfares is the McGuire Building. Note the sign over same. View No. 2 emphasizes W. 125th Street and upon which appears the arched span carrying the subway lines at Broadway.

May 4, 1938.
Views 1 and 2

P.L. Sperr

60 E. 42nd Street, (Lincoln Building) south side, west of Persh-ing Square (general view northwestward). Prominently shown are the two huge Rockefeller Center units; The 70-storied R. C. A. Building and its small R. K. O. Building. Merging into the former, in the foreground, are the Fred. F. French and the Ruppert Buildings. Central Park is on the right. Beyond, are the North (Hudson) River, the George Washington Bridge and the Jersey highlands.

1937-8

Alexander Alland

This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N.Y." by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.
title: General view - [Manhattan - 42nd Street (East) - Lincoln Building (Northwest).]

text:
George Washington Bridge: A set of 2 views southwestward from Dr. Chas. V. Paterno's estate on the east bank of the North (Hudson) River, showing this span connecting Manhattan with Jersey thru a ribbon of steel. The castellated structure at the left is the home of the aforementioned individual and is at this time being razed to provide an apartment site. For views see Cabrini Blvd.

August 23, 1938.
Views 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr
title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [North (Hudson) River.]

text:

title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [North (Hudson) River.]

text:
The George Washington Bridge at night as photographed southward from Fort Tryon Park in Manhattan.

1939

Alexander Alland

This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portrait of N. Y." by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IRGV.
title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [View of the bridge at night from Fort Tryon Park.]

text:
Rush Construction of World's Longest Suspension Bridge. Right, construction work on one of the piers of the great Hudson River Bridge which will be opened in 1932 at a cost of about 170 million. The Bridge will connect Manhattan(lower right) between 178th Street and 179th Street and Fort Lee, New Jersey(left) where another pier is shown. The distance between the two piers, from which the Bridge will be suspended, is 3,500 feet -- over twice the length of the longest suspension bridge at present
(Camden-Philadelphia span).
n.d.  Underwood and Underwood
title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [Construction of the world's longest suspension bridge.]
